bSTKIx-s6.memHandModelNotes:
Patch size means that these kites need map units in any combination that are together at least 530 ha in size.  There is no evidence for road density avoidance.

I removed the freshwater only limitation. Meyer (1995) states that they utilize fresh and brackish marsh. Was not really doing anything anyway because water buffers were not selected. MJR 14 June 2007.

references.R90CEL01SEGP: Cely, J.E. and J.A. Sorrow. 1990. The American swallow-tailed kite in South Carolina. Nongame and Heritage Trust Fund publ. No. 1. South Carolina Wildl. And Mar. Resour. Dept., Columbia, SC.
references.B37BEN01NAUS: Bent, A.C. 1937. Life histories of North American birds of prey. Part 1. Bull. U.S. Natl. Mus. 137. 409 pp.
references.A96CAR02NAUS: Carter, M., G. Fenwick, C. Hunter, D. Pashley, D. Petit, J. Price, and J. Trapp. 1996. Watchlist 1996:For the future. Field Notes 50(3):238-240.
references.A87MIL01SEGP: Millsap, B. A.1987.  Summer concentration of American swallow-tailed kites at Lake Okeechobee, FL, with comments on post-breeding movements. Florida Field Naturalist. 15(4):85-112.

references.B88PAL01NAUS: Palmer, R. S., editor. 1988. Handbook of North American birds. Vol. 4. [Diurnal raptors, part 1]. Yale University Press, New Haven. vii + 433 pp.
references.B83NAT01NAUS: National Geographic Society (NGS). 1983. Field guide to the birds of North America. National Geographic Society, Washington, D.C.

references.B89STI01NAUS: Stiles, F.G., and A.F. Skutch. 1989. A guide to the birds of Costa Rica. Comstock Publ. Associates, Cornell University Press, Ithaca, New York. 511 pp.
